rename.from: W0120 should not be raised on `return`

body:
There's a few test cases in `W0120` that I don't quite understand:

```python
def test_return_for():
    """else + return is not acceptable."""
    for i in range(10):
        if i % 2:
            return i
    else:  # [useless-else-on-loop]
        print('math is broken')
    return None

def test_return_while():
    """else + return is not acceptable."""
    while True:
        return 1
    else:  # [useless-else-on-loop]
        print('math is broken')
    return None
```

Why should `W0120` be raised here?

I'm not sure. It feels like they should indeed also not raise. Have you looked at the commit and PR that added them? Perhaps there is a discussion there?

Edit: I just did and in the commit message of nine years ago they actually discuss this and there seems to have been an internal discussion about this at the time (at logilab I guess?). See: https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/commit/1c19e05887bb6abb26dd54cffa8229226a4ca36c

Looking at the last line of the message I think there is a case to be made to remove this. I would vote in favour I think.
Removing those tests should make the PR ready for review, brb

issue.title: Fix `useless-else-on-loop` false positive

body:
> they actually discuss this and there seems to have been an internal discussion about this at the time

@DanielNoord That looks like the commit intending to do what @tushar-deepsource wants to do and permit `return` alongside `break`. Looks like they reversed themselves about a month later: 31e6b776a, giving the current behavior.

> Looking at the last line of the message I think there is a case to be made to remove this.

Meaning I think they expected they might go to the current behavior.

> Looking at the last line of the message I think there is a case to be made to remove this. I would vote in favour I think.

I guess I don't see a strong reason for the change; it just causes churn.
